item.title: Diablo 4 May Bring Back Old Seasonal Content in the Future
item.description:
Diablo 4 recently teased that some popular seasonal mechanics could return sometime in the future. Though nothing is set in stone yet, the Diablo 4 development team would like to find a way to keep or iterate on popular game mechanics, even after their seasons are done.

As a live service game, Diablo 4 puts out a new season of content every few months, each revolving around a particular gimmick. While some features stick around afterward, most go away with the next major update. For example, Sins of the Horadrim, the current season, features the temporary Horadric Strongrooms, Jewels, and Spells, alongside the evergreen Escalating Nightmares feature in Diablo 4 .

Old Diablo 4 Seasonal Features Could Return

However, according to the director of Diablo social and content marketing, Adam Fletcher, Blizzard is considering adjustments to this model in the future. While fielding a question from D4 fan ACosmicPhoenix on Twitter about whether Diablo 4 Season 10’s Chaos Armor would be an eternal or seasonal feature, Fletcher confirmed the development team “wants to keep things or maybe evolve things even more if they work well.” That said, he was sure to emphasize that if such a change were to happen, the features might not return immediately in the next season.

This would be a net positive for Diablo 4 as a whole. While many players enjoy seasonal strength like Diablo 4 Season 2's Vampiric Powers or Season 7’s Witchcraft Powers, the most popular features in Diablo 4 tend to be the eternal, evergreen ones. For example, Season 4, Loot Reborn, was widely considered one of the most popular Diablo 4 seasons, as it introduced fundamental changes to the game’s core rewards system. If other seasonal features and changes were to become eternal as well, many fans would have an easier time becoming invested in them and not experiencing FOMO if they happen to take a break from the game for a few months.

All Diablo 4 Seasons and Major Features

Number

Name

Release Date

Major Features

1

Season of the Malignant

July 20, 2023

Malignant Monsters, Hearts, Tunnels

2

Season of Blood

Vampiric Powers, Hunter's Acclaim, Pact Armor

3

Season of the Construct

January 23, 2024

Seneschal Construct, Arcane Tremors, Vaults

4

Season of Loot Reborn

5

Season of the Infernal Hordes

August 6, 2024

Infernal Hordes

6

Season of Hatred Rising

October 8, 2024

Realmwalkers, Seething Realm, Progression Updates

7

Season of Witchcraft

January 21, 2025

Witchcraft Powers, Headhunts, Occult Gems, Rootholds

8

Belial's Return

April 29, 2025

Boss Powers, Reliquary System, Deadly Apparitions

9

Sins of the Horadrim

July 1, 2025

Horadiric Spells, Strongrooms, Jewels, Nightmare Dungeon Escalation

10

Infernal Chaos

September 23, 2025

Chaos Powers, Armor, Rifts, Infernal Hordes Update

Of course, it is important to note this is not confirmation Diablo 4 is making these changes, or which features will be iterated on if it does – only that it is on the team’s radar. Players should be sure to temper their expectations until they hear an official announcement from the developers.

September 16 is going to be a big day for Diablo 4 fans, as the Developer Update Livestream for Season 10 is set to take place. With the season itself scheduled to begin on September 23, this month is gearing up to be an exciting month for the heroes of Sanctuary.

item.title: How to Get Unlimited Cash in Borderlands 4
item.description:
Even on a planet that's been cut off from the rest of the galaxy, players will still need Cash if they want to buy their necessities in Borderlands 4 . The economy hasn't changed much on Kairos, but if you want guns, equipment, ammo, and more guns, you'll need to have a lot of money at the ready.

Thankfully, money comes somewhat easy in Borderlands 4 , especially during the campaign. However, players can run out of it just as quickly if they find themselves relying on vending machines a lot. If you want an efficient way to get what is basically unlimited cash, then here's a simple trick you can do.

Best Way to Get Money in Borderlands 4

The easiest and fastest way to get Cash is to farm bosses or Ripper Drill Site encounters. In Borderlands 4 , players can use Encore machines to instantly reset these big combat encounters. Using an Encore machine costs Cash, but the amount you have to pay is nothing compared to the profit you can make, especially if you end up getting good gear.

Once you complete a repeatable encounter, pick up the most valuable pieces of loot you can find and sell them at any of the vending machines next to the nearby Encore machine. You'll usually get enough money to break even just by selling one purple-rarity weapon, and if you can get several of them (or just sell multiple blues or greens), you'll make more than enough Cash to turn a profit.

Some of the best places to farm includes:

  • Any of the main story bosses
  • Any of the three optional Vault bosses
  • Bramblesong in the Stoneblood Forest Augur Mine in Terminus Range
  • Sidney Pointylegs in the Prospects Drill Site in the Fadefields

We recommend Sidney Pointylegs and Bramblesong here because they drop some strong legendary loot that players will be able to use well regardless of what their build is:

  • Sidney drops the Swarm , a legendary grenade that releases target-seeking darts. Each dart can hit a single target multiple times.
  • Bramblesong drops the legendary Convergence shotgun, another weapon that's all about dealing massive damage to a single target.

If you can get both the Swarm and Convergence, you'll pretty much be set for your other boss-hunting endeavors. These are great on any Vault Hunter, though Vex can probably get the most use of them thanks to her Kinetic attunement and ability to cause Bleeding with Kinetic damage.

If you want to make extra cash without repeatedly farming bosses or while doing the campaign, grab some contracts from the bounty boards in safe zones, then do those as you're progressing through the campaign.

Borderlands 4
8 /10

item.title: Neil Druckmann Hints at Last of Us 3
item.description:
Neil Druckman may have hinted at the possibility of a third game in The Last of Us series while discussing the show. While the second game faced its fair share of controversy, it was undeniably successful and left many fans wanting more after a somewhat open ending. There's still no official confirmation of a third The Last of Us game , but Ellie's story may not be over yet.

It's been five years since the second game was first released, but the franchise has still had a recent string of wins. In May, both The Last of Us Part 1 and Part 2 became some of Amazon's best-selling PS5 games as the second season of its HBO show wrapped up and propelled the franchise back into popularity. The show was renewed for a third season, and while Naughty Dog is gearing up for the release of another game, Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet , a third Last of Us title may not be off the table.

Neil Druckmann Suggests Naughty Dog Has Ideas for The Last of Us Part 3

In an interview with Variety, Druckmann said "other things are coming" after leaving the show and that the studio had "looked at ideas" for what could be in The Last of Us Part 3 immediately after wrapping up the second game. Ultimately, Naughty Dog decided to go with a new IP, but Druckmann said, "we have some other ideas that we’d like to explore" after the release of Intergalactic , which may be good news for Last of Us fans. Industry insider and leaker Daniel Ritchman has previously claimed that The Last of Us Part 3 has begun casting, even though the studio has been quiet about it, if that's true.

In an earlier interview, the Last of Us creator said he focuses mostly on one game at a time, as working on one game is already "all-consuming." Druckmann doubled down on that approach in the Variety conversation, saying Naughty Dog doesn't plan too far in advance, instead focusing on what's immediately in front of them. That means if The Last of Us Part 3 is real, it will likely be a while before fans hear official word of it.

As for Naughty Dog's upcoming release, there could be a long wait for that game. While leaving the HBO show gives Druckmann more time to focus on game development, an insider has said Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet may not come out before 2027. Additionally, Druckmann himself has said the title has a long way to go before it's ready. Still, the apparent Last of Us tease may be exciting news for fans as they wait for more.

item.title: Silksong: How to Get to Weavenest Atla
item.description:
Weavenest Atla is an area whose entrance players will have definitely seen in the first hour of Hollow Knight: Silksong , but would have no idea how to open it. Despite the door being available to look at from the start of the game, it's not until the end of the first Act that players will acquire an ability and be able to open the door that leads to Weavenest Atla.

This is one of the smaller areas in the game, but it has a very important NPC that can change the player's gameplay and playstyle. Here's how to find the ability locking players out of the area and the location of the map in Hollow Knight: Silksong .

How to Get to Weavenest Atla in Silksong

To reach the Weavenest Atla , you will need to progress through the main story until you reach Bellhart, and a new objective appears: The Threadspun Town . For this objective, you will have to go into Shellwood , acquire the wall jump ability, and then head right to defeat the Widow . Doing this will get you the Needolin Skill , which is necessary for Weavenest Atla.

Go to the Bellway Station and fast travel to Bone Bottom . Head left and down into Moss Grotto , but make your way right to find a large weaver-shaped door that you can open now. Stand next to the door and press Triangle/Y on your controller or D if you are playing on the Keyboard . Head through the door to reach Weavenest Atla.

Weavenest Atla Map Location in Silksong

The map for Weavenest Atla is not far away from the starting location. After opening the door, keep going straight and head right to find two glowing cylinders that you can hit . This will make the mechanism in the room behind start working, which jets you down to the bottom of the area. However, before going there, you can interact with the rune tablet to find the map . There are quite a few things in this area that you can get, such as a Spool Fragment , Mask Shard , a boss in one corner of the area, and an NPC that upgrades your Hunter’s Crest .

The Needolin Skill can be used in front of any NPC to make them sing and opens a few doors located throughout the game. Most of these doors lead to different locations or valuable tools.

item.title: Indiana Jones and the Great Circle's DLC Reminds Me Why I Fell In Love With The Franchise In The First Place
item.description:
I was born at the worst time to be an Indiana Jones fan. While I had been subjected to the original Indiana Jones trilogy many times when I was a toddler, I was a bit too young for it to sink in properly. And by the time I was old enough to really start enjoying movies, Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull was hitting the big screen. I can wholeheartedly say Kingdom of the Crystal Skull is not a good movie now, but to my little nine-year-old brain sitting in a theater for one of the first times, it was the greatest movie ever made, and my misguided love for what's widely considered to be the franchise's worst entry is what finally kicked my younger self into gear.

I became an Indiana Jones mega fan overnight. I used my pocket money to buy all the DVDs. I begged my mum to buy Indiana Jones and the Emperor 's Tomb for my original Xbox when we passed by the now-defunct Gamestation in my hometown. I hyperfixated on Indiana Jones so much that I convinced myself my life's calling was to become an archaeologist.

As you can probably tell from me writing this article and not digging up fossils on Time Team , my nine-year-old self didn't get his dream career, but I've carried his deep love for the Indiana Jones franchise with me for almost two decades now. But, boy, has it been a struggle.

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle Saved My Love of The Franchise

Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny Broke Me

The original Indiana Jones trilogy has always held a very special place in my heart, and while Kingdom of the Crystal Skull is far from a good movie, I have a lot of nostalgia for it. Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny , however, broke me.

The first Indiana Jones movie I was getting to see on the big screen since I was nine, my excitement was through the roof in the lead up to I ndiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny 's release back in June 2023. My excitement was so fervent, in fact, that my wife and friends felt it necessary to gently warn me about getting my hopes up.

"But James Mangold is directing!" I'd say. "Phoebe Waller-Bridge is in it! We love Fleabag !" I'd exclaim. "And sure, Harrison Ford is getting on a bit, but Indy's the one character he really, truly cares about! It can't be bad!" This was going to be it. The return to form the franchise so desperately needed.

Of course, I was wrong. I sat there watching Dial of Destiny on opening night, and though it technically ticked all the boxes of things I wanted to see in a new Indiana Jones movie, it all just felt a bit...wrong. Everything just felt a little bit off, from the characterization of Indy to the action choreography to the plot and central mystery at the heart of the whole thing.

I left the movie theater a shell of my former self, and I genuinely fell into a bit of a depression for about a week. I was convinced that this was the final death knell in one of my favorite franchises of all time, and that broke not just my heart, but my nine-year-old self's as well.

Like a Giant-Sized Angel, Indiana Jones and the Great Circle Rescued Me

I tried to learn my lesson after Dial of Destiny . I had been eagerly anticipating MachineGames' Indiana Jones project since that very first typewriter trailer back in January 2021, and the closer Indiana Jones and the Great Circle got, the less I could contain my excitement, though I tried my hardest to.

December 2024 finally rolled around, and reviews for Indiana Jones and the Great Circle looked pretty great across the board. But reviews aren't the be-all and end-all. Sure, most outlets were in agreement that it was a great next step for the franchise, but I couldn't let myself get too excited. Not again.

Though I was originally going to wait for its full launch, I caved and paid for Indiana Jones and the Great Circle 's Premium Edition upgrade so I could play a few days early. And I'm still so glad I did, because the second I spotted Alfred Molina's Satipo over Indy's shoulder and realized what the game's first mission was, I knew it was all going to be okay.

What followed was 20+ hours of pure bliss. Indiana Jones and the Great Circle really felt like the complete package for a lifelong Indy fan like myself, and while the game isn't perfect, it gave me exactly what I wanted and then some. The Great Circle managed to tell its own strong standalone story while still paying homage to the groundbreaking silver screen entries that came before it, and in one fell swoop, it managed to restore my faith in the entire Indiana Jones franchise.

Indiana Jones: The Order of Giants Is The Perfect Distillation of the Franchise's Formula

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle was more than enough Indy content to keep me satisfied for a while, but MachineGames has just served up a delicious bite-sized dessert, and I couldn't resist. Indiana Jones and the Great Circle 's The Order of Giants DLC is a short but sweet 3-4 hour side adventure that takes place during the main game's Vatican section, and while it too isn't without its flaws, it's still the latest reminder of why I love this franchise so much.

Indiana Jones: The Order of Giants has it all. Indy's once again trying to get to the bottom of a mythological mystery, all while being pursued by fascists. Along the way, he uses his almost superhuman knowledge of ancient history to solve some puzzles, he raids some tombs, he faces off against a secret cult, and comes face to face with a figure ripped right out of Greek mythology. And throughout all of that, there are countless fist fights, whip swings, and self-aware one-liners.

Where Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny felt like it was just ticking franchise staples off a checklist, The Order of Giants revels in each and every item, understanding all the while exactly why the franchise is so loved in the first place, and in turn, reassuring me once again that the Indiana Jones I know and love isn't dead just yet. It's just picking itself back up off the cliff, fedora in hand.
